title: 104_hr4030
content: The "New Jersey Marine Ecosystem Protection Act of 1996" aims to preserve and restore marine wildlife in the New York Bight by closing the Mud Dump Site and ending the disposal of contaminated dredged material in that area. After September 1, 1997, no one can dump dredged material at the Mud Dump Site unless it is for remediation purposes. Only Category I and Category II dredged material can be dumped at the site after the enactment of the Act. After September 1, 1997, dumping dredged material at the Mud Dump Site is only allowed for remediation purposes. Dumping requires certification and a finding from the Secretary of the Army, ensuring no increase in ocean bottom elevation beyond 65 feet below the surface. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, in collaboration with the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of the Army, will develop a remediation and restoration plan for the Mud Dump Site and surrounding areas. The site will be designated as the Historic Area Remediation Site for disposal of contaminated material. The Historic Area Remediation Site, managed under part 228 of title 40, Code of Federal Regulations, must reduce impacts to acceptable levels and be remediated with uncontaminated dredged material meeting Category I standards. The Secretary of the Army and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will modify the Environmental Assessment. The Army and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will modify environmental assessment activities at the Mud Dump Site in accordance with this Act. SEC. 4. TERMINATION OF OCEAN DUMPING OF DREDGED MATERIAL OFF COAST OF NEW JERSEY: Starting September 1, 1997, no dredged material can be dumped in the New York Bight Apex or New York-New Jersey Harbor. The EPA cannot designate new dumping sites in the New York Bight Apex, and the Army cannot issue permits for dumping without following this Act. SEC. 5. VIOLATIONS. Any violation of section 3 (a) or (b) or section 4(a) shall be treated as a violation of title I of the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972 (33 U.S.C. 1411 et seq.). SEC. 6. DISPOSAL ALTERNATIVES. SEC. 6. DISPOSAL ALTERNATIVES. The Secretary of the Army, in cooperation with relevant authorities, may establish a dredged material disposal facility in the Port of New York and New Jersey. Costs will be covered by non-Federal interests. $260,000,000 is authorized for this purpose. In this Act, terms are defined based on the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972. Category I and Category II dredged material are defined according to specific guidelines. The term "Mud Dump Site" refers to a designated area by the Environmental Protection Agency. The Environmental Protection Agency designates the New York Bight Dredged Material Disposal Site in the North Atlantic Ocean for dredged material from the Port of New York and New Jersey. The New York Bight Apex is defined as specific ocean waters in the Atlantic Ocean.
